Colt owns property that is worth $49,000, with a basis of $47,000. Colt sells the property to an organization that is tax-exempt under Section 501(c)(3) for $33,000. How much gain or loss does Colt recognize due to his transfer of the property to the 501(c)(3) organization? (1) $0 (2) $1,347 (3) $2,000 (4) $3,000
https://www.law.cornell.edu/uscode/text/26/1011 Correct! Under Section 1011(b) the donor recovers basis proportionately.

Heaven owns property that is worth $50,000, with a basis of $36,000. Heaven dies and leaves the property to Violet. Several years later, Violet sells the property for $59,000. How much gain or loss does Violet recognize due to her sale of the property for $59,000? (1) $0 (2) $8,000 (3) $9,000 (4) $10,960 (5) $13,000 (6) $16,000 (7) $23,000

https://www.law.cornell.edu/uscode/text/26/1014 Correct! Under Section 1014(a), the basis of the asset is set to the fair market value at the time of death. Therefore Violet recognizes $59,000 - $50,000 = $9,000 on the subsequent sale.

Isaac owns property that is worth $41,000, with a basis of $32,000. Isaac sells the property to an organization that is tax-exempt under Section 501(c)(3) for $27,000. Mylah owns property that is worth $39,000, with a basis of $41,000. Mylah gives the property to Sullivan. Mylah and Sullivan are family members, but not spouses. Several years later, Sullivan sells the property for $33,000. How much gain or loss does Sullivan recognize due to their sale of the property for $33,000? (1) -$8,000 (2) -$6,821 (3) -$6,000 (4) -$5,000 (5) -$4,000 (6) $0 (7) $10,000

https://www.law.cornell.edu/uscode/text/26/1015 Correct! Because the value at the initial transfer was less than the basis, the dual basis rule applies as described in Section 1015(a). Because the ultimate sale price was less than the value of the asset at the time of transfer, the recipient must use that value as the basis for determining loss. Sullivan therefore recognizes $33,000 - $39,000 = -$6,000.

https://www.law.cornell.edu/uscode/text/26/1015 Correct! Because the value at the initial transfer was less than the basis, the dual basis rule applies as described in Section 1015(a). Here, however, the ultimate sale price was greater than the basis in the hands of the transferor, so the recipient uses the transferred basis. Kenneth therefore recognizes $30,000 - $28,000 = $2,000.

Jordan owns property that is worth $43,000, with a basis of $39,000. Jordan sells the property to an organization that is tax-exempt under Section 501(c)(3) for $33,000. How much gain or loss does Jordan recognize due to his transfer of the property to the 501(c)(3) organization? (1) $0 (2) $3,070 (3) $4,000 (4) $5,000
https://www.law.cornell.edu/uscode/text/26/1011 Correct! Under Section 1011(b) the donor recovers basis proportionately.

https://www.law.cornell.edu/uscode/text/26/1014 Correct! Under Section 1014(a), the basis of the asset is set to the fair market value at the time of death. Therefore Colette recognizes $47,000 - $44,000 = $3,000 on the subsequent sale.
